Mr. Joseph Ward
of Charlotte in the state of Virginia
April 23rd 1792

1st These lines I waite for to unfold
A certain match as I've been told
The man a Cook the girl a Brewer
The thing is strange but seldom truer
2nd This cook he had a certain mess
He often gives this pretty lass
He Cook'd so well and fed with broth
[...ial?] she took a second growth
[3rd?  ] was at a loss then what to do
As he'd cooked now she must brew
She brewed at first without success
For cook refused to join the mess
4th Then when she took another scheme
Employing all the Brewer's [means?]
To view the thing how [she?  ] look
To turn a Brewer into a Cook
5th Old pat the mother of all the clan
She studied the stars to form a plan
Both young and old Black and white
Studied planets all one night
6th When all the affair was brewed and done
She call'd young [J?]ack her loving son
Saying take with you Billy your Brother
We'll stay at home, me and your father
7th This is the dose that you [  ]
Unless he will your Sister [have? ]
If he consents fly with all hast[e]
Down to Tom Reads to make a []fast
8th Then they both to Cook did come
Saying heres your portion deaths your doom
Unless you will our Sister marry
Do it to day no longer tarry
9th This Cook refused with all his might
Then there began a bloody fight
At last said Cook with weeping eyes
I'll marry your Sister let me rise
10th Then said young Jack theres one thing yet
This day you shall your license get
And marry her before tis night
Or we shall have another fight
11th Then said poor Cook now let me rise
I suppose needs must when the devil drives
If I must have her, she must do
I've [lay'd] her well sometime ago
12th When the parson came, the Cook was Confounded
That by the Brewers he was Surrounded
That he'd no way to turn his head
He took the dose and went to bed

13th A Midnight thought came in his? Mind

      What sort of names his Brothers unclear
      There never so will matched? of unclear
      As Bakers, Brewers? and of Cooks

14th My Brother Billy married a Baker

      unclear married a Brewer? the Devil take her
      My Brother Ben married another
      last line unclear

(signed) Mr. Joseph Ward

             April 23rd 1792

The rights of nature are those which nature points 

out to all men.

   Speaking of hell Cicero says you will not find an Old 
   Woman weak enough to believe it.
         Humon nature have been always devoted to 
     errors. But those errors not always the cause 
     of blood shed.

Such moving sounds from such a gentle touch, 
So little she concerned? and we so much.
The bumbling strings about her fingers crowd?, 
And till their joy, for every unclear, aloud. 
Small force thou needs to make them unclear, 
Touch’d by that hand who would not tremble too?
Here? love takes stand and, while she charms the ear.
Empties his quiver on the listening? deer.
Musick so softens and disarms the mind,
That not one arrow can resistance find.
Thus the fair tyrant? unclear the prize
And acts herself the triumph of her eyes.
Lo, Nero? once with harp? in hand survey’d
His flaming Rome, and, while it burn’d, he play’d

The roses that my brain? surround
Were natives of the dale;
Scarce pluck’d, and in a garland bound?
Before their hue grew pale
My trial? unclear would thus be froze
If unclear torn from thee
For what the road? is to the rose
My Emma is to me
Two doves I found like new fallen snow
So white the beautious? pair
The birds on Emma I’ll bestow
They’re like her unclear fair
May they of our connubial love
A happy omen be
And such unclear 
May Emma share with me

The gentle swan with graceful pride 
Her glossy? plumage loves
And sailing down the silver tide 
Divides the whispering waves;
The silver tide that wand’ring flows
Sweet to the bird must be;
But not as sweet blithe cupid knows
As Emma is to me
A parent bird in plaintive mood
on yonder fruit tree sing
But this the unclear nest she viewed?
Which hold her callow young
Tho dear to her maternal heart
The genial? brood may be
Yet not as dear the thousandth have?
As Emma is to

Mary the wise of Old was thought
A mighty woman of worth
Her plans was to a Country ?ought
The Empire of the Earth
At length she died and was no more
Her plans was all for gotton
Her fame that was at a Distant shore ?
Was with her Dead & rotton


There rose a mighty man of worth
Henry the word of old

Down in a hulk lies forlorn unclear the joy of unclear
No more he'l hear the Tempest howling for death has brought
His form was of the manliest beauty, his Hart unclear soft unclear
Faithfully before he did his duty unclear now he’s gone aloft

I that once was plowman, a Saylor am now.
Ho lark that aloft in the sky
Ever fluttered his wings to give speed to the plow
was so gay or as cheerful as I.
unclear my friend was a unclear on board a Kings Ship
And asked me to go just to sea for a trip
and he talked of such things, Thus saylor's were Kings.
and so teasing and keep and so teasing and keep
thus I left my poor plough to go ploughing
No longer the horn, call me up the morn
& the unconstant wind
that made me for to go & leave my deer behind 
I did not much like to be a board a Ship
where in danger there is no door  to creep out
I like this jolly unclear like good unclear & unclear

unclear by comet or unclear I arise not like unclear

See unclear with the load unclear
of a whole garden's pride
The nosegay totters at her breast
And miser like of weath possesed
Its treasure seekes to hide
The blushing Rose, in contrast sweet
Its fragrant leaf displays
Whilst pinks that Sprang beneath her feet
Now feel her heart with rapture beat
While she her unclear surveys
Go gaudy flowers now in despight?
Presume those charms to shade
The rising sun still puts to flight
The envious clouds of parting night
that would his Reign invade
Go seek the bosom, swoln with pride
Spleen/B’tween? envy and despair
There spread your ample foliage wide
and like the pagan temple hide
the fiend thats worshiped there

Listen to the Vow of Love
O! Listen to the vow of Love, he calls my Eliza unclear grow,
The unclear sow seeds beneath the field,
The unclear Birds in vow to sow,
To softer joy, let splendor yield.
O! Listen, Listen to the vow of Love,
Where flowers their blooming sweet inhale
By Eliza let us fondly stray from
Where whispering Love breathes forth form his tale
And unclearsing their artful unclear

And leave the town’sunclear house,

A dieu a dieu my only life my honor calls me from thee. Remember thour't a Soldier's wife those tears but ill becom thee. What tho by duty I am called when thundering cannons rattle. Where valour's self might stand appal'd where valour's self might stand appall'd when on the wings of thy true love to heaven above thy fervent orisons had flown the tender pray'r thou puts up there shall call a guardian Angel down . Shall call a guardian Angel down to watch me in the battle. 
My safety thy fair truth shall be as sword & unclear serving
My life shall be, more dear to me
Because of they preserving
